YVGtYABLYGjiNWx6iNBaog.text: Tiny. Packed. Dismissive staff. Do not go without a reservation as walk-ins are not an option in reality. Can only make a reservation greater than 24 hours in advance. Referred to the location at St. Paul's "that will have lots of room" and ran into exactly the same thing after a trek over there... At least the St. Paul's staff were polite. Seemed very expensive.

2BsdRIMkEc--31qIoWb2wQ.text: Bea's has got that old school "ladies that lunch" vibe going on with its floral chairs and wallpaper. I've come here twice: once for a takeaway quiche and salad that I ate at one of the beautiful parks in Bloomsbury and once to eat a pasta salad at the restaurant. Both times I got a cupcake. They have so many kinds, I couldn't resist!The food is a little pricey, but that's understandable since the quality is very good and the service is friendly. Will definitely be back to Bea's for tea some time.

Yeg7VVNU77VcPT00ajE6tg.text: The cakes and sweets in the Afternoon Tea are nice but I feel overall it's a victim of its own success. Too little staff  to cope with how busy it gets and too much confusion. We made a reservation, we were seated, asked if we were here for the afternoon tea (we were), asked what tea we'd like, and it was all served. This gave the impression of table service. We waited to be asked if we'd like more tea or for the bill. In the end we had to go to the counter to ask for these things. When I queried them on this later, they informed me that they're too busy to offer a table service. That'd be fine if that was made clear to us (a simple "If you want anything else, please come to the counter" would have sufficed, when we were served the tea.) There is a slight assumption that you've been before and you know what to expect. Overall this made me feel quite embarrassed that I had not known it was counter service, rather than table service.Unfortunately, I'll give this place a miss in the future.  Maybe one day I'll pop in to buy a cupcake to take away but that'll be it.

d-k282TIIhxMI2ss7OJZmQ.text: I entertained a friend this weekend, and she was eager to experience afternoon tea in London. Being students, we were interested in something slightly more affordable than the afternoon teas offered by the fancier establishments. Bea's offered three levels of afternoon tea, ranging from 9 quid to 21 (if i remember correctly). The scones were delicious, and the waiters working there were friendly and accommodating with the variety of requests made by our five person group. The only reason I give four stars and not five was that most of the cakes offered involved peanut butter, and though I love all things peanut butter, my friend is not a fan, and was thus unable to enjoy a number of the desserts.

kQ0IBNQFsrFpnRVyJG3wYA.text: It's businesses like Bea's that are putting Bloomsbury back on the map. Even a few years ago, Bloomsbury was a very overlooked area, but you'd be foolish to overlook it now. This wasn't my first trip to Bea's, since I live a few minutes walk away I can pop in whenever I want. The only thing holding me back from doing that is having no one to go with (so lonely!). You see, Bea's is best enjoyed with a special someone - either close friends or that extra special someone. You could go on your own, but that's a slippery slope towards cake addiction! You have been warned! There's a few tables outside and inside is very nice, but today I want to talk to you about picnics! Bloomsbury is a great area for public open spaces that are perfect for picnics. Given the lovely spell of weather we've been having recently - Bea's afternoon tea picnic offer was an offer I couldn't refuse. For the same price as their regular sweet afternoon tea (£9.90 per person), Bea's will provide you with a full picnic set to take where you please for the afternoon. We're not talking plastic cups here - it's a proper wicker picnic basket. complete with metal cutlery, ceramic plates and tea cups, plus a handy bottle opener! (should you like to take a bottle of something along with you). You just need to leave a credit card or some ID with them until you return the basket. The tea consists of a handmade scone, clotted cream and jam in little pots, a handmade cupcake, a mini Valrhona brownie, a mini Belgian Blondie, and a mini meringue. With the picnic set you also get a thermos of hot water and some tea bags of your choice. We also added some delicious mini baguettes at £3 per person. All the food was perfect! Just the right amount for an afternoon and the right balance of richness so as not to be too full-on. The cupcakes were fantastic! Other highlights were the meringue and the mini baguettes, which were unexpectedly good and full of flavour. The only teeny negatives were that there thermos was a bit leaky (but lovely staff who put together our picnic did warn us). The other was that there were no napkins, but we got by. When you compare Bea's to the cost of a coffee and an inferior cake from a high street coffee chain, it's a bit of a bargain! Sure you could just go to Tesco and come away with a lot more food for the same money, but Bea's is special. You can tell that it's fresh, and made by really skilled people, and that no corners have been cut when it comes to the quality of ingredients. I'd highly recommend anyone to go to Bea's normally, but the picnic offer is really a 6-Star experience! We had a lovely afternoon that really would be hard to beat!

eCR5Voi7rHl63-MqI-2p8A.text: If you're looking for fresh, well-prepared food, this is your place. I should note that there's a disconnect between the great food and ambiance of the place: the food is delicious, but the interior decor could be better. I suppose,though, that with such reasonable prices, one cannot complain. For 5 pounds if you're dining in (and only 3 pounds for take-out!) you get a small plate of three food options. They have different selections every day. You feel good knowing everything is prepared fresh, and the food is really great!

m4haQT15V91U2FwJS4wdVw.text: We took a visiting friend to her first high tea there and was disappointed. The put us at a tiny table for 2 even though the place was empty. Although the sweets were good, the scone was crumbly and very dry and the sandwiches were all dry thick hard bread with very little inside. The worst part was the tea. All of us had luke warm tea with little taste. dIt was embarrassing to bring a friend there and have to apologize and explain that this wasn't what we expected. Our server was nice and that's why I gave it 2 stars.

Ri4t0YFKFs-vrYPqd_lFwg.text: I'd like to think that I know a little about food, drink and service, given I've worked in the industry for over 10 years.We all know that with restaurants/ cafes, it's a bit like a spaghetti western: there are the good, bad and ugly.Bea's is good.Not only are the staff and atmosphere welcoming, the selection of food is particularly yummy.To the detractors, I would say it may not be perfect, but it's like having a meal at a friend's place: when the company is good and you're in nice surroundings, surely you can forgive any minor niggles?

0bmhxw8BwdksyXzA3vCjfw.text: So cute. So darn cute that I really, really wanted to like the cupcakes. Sadly the lemon strawberry one was tasty yet dry. My husband had a chocolate fudge cupcake and his was overdone: hard, dry and just not good. Sigh. I'll give it another chance because the food they were putting out for lunch looked amazing. But then again so did the cupcakes...

eRGzXyHucGR0xtPQn2V5vw.text: I went back, my first visit must have just been a massive offday as it was great the second time I went... Glad I retried it.Did a full review on my blog.

kA2nTLXXl2p-EOJoObHsjg.text: I came here to get an early-morning weekday breakfast with the always-lovely Lizzie G this morning, as Bea's is just around the corner from my office AND is open at 8am.  I feel, though, that my breakfast visit gives me quite a different perspective of Bea's than everyone else, because I didn't have to fight for a table (the place had just opened when we popped in) and I didn't get any cakes or the 'afternoon tea' experience which everyone else seems to come to Bea's for.What I can say, though, is that Bea certainly wooed me with her warm and gooey porridge with help-yourself toppings.  Toppings available: dried fruit, cinnamon and sugar, brown sugar, milk, honey, dessicated coconut and mixed nuts.  Toppings on my porridge: dried fruit, cinnamon and sugar, brown sugar, milk, honey, dessicated coconut and mixed nuts.What can I say?  I'm a sucker for a buffet.  Bea's interior was modern and dark with subtle feminine notes.  Yeah, um.  That's all I really have to say about that.  Just thought I'd throw it out there.Being the piggies--I mean good Yelpers--that we are, Lizzie and I went back for a cheese and herb scone.  A pitch-perfect cheese and herb scone.  Crumbly yet soft, delicious and totally nom-able: I put some leftovers in my bag to have as a heavenly mid-morning snack at my desk.  Scone-alicious!I drank some JING English Breakfast tea, which I was pretty stoked for, having just heard about JING via the Yelp Talk boards yesterday.  Sorry to say, I wasn't particularly blown away by the tea, but that could just be down to unnecessarily high expectations.  Had I not just researched JING tea online the day before and had been expecting it to be the kind of tea that Jesus serves to Jane Austen at the Big Tea House in the Sky, I probably would have happily gluggled my pot from Bea's this morning and said, 'Mmm, tea, caffeine, more please!'  But, there you have it.I do have to say: the rotating lunch menu which is available to view online looks AMAZING.  I may just have to pop up here for a takeaway lunch sometime soon.

0JGDvbXmGQZTrRdmk6zGhQ.text: I went to Beas of Bloomsbury specifically for their sweet tea, so this rating is just for that.For £16, the sweet tea comes with 1 pot of tea/coffee, 1 scone, 1 cupcake, 3 tiny pieces of fudge, 1 small meringue, and 1 small piece of marshmallow. I was surprised by how little I get for the price, but I guess it has to be worth it for it to be so popular. I first started with the scone, it was very crumbly and buttery, and if it was warmed, it would have tasted even better, but unfortunately, it is too good on it's own and makes the clotted cream redundant. coincidentally, clotted cream is my favourite component of afternoon tea, so I was a little disappointed that I didn't get to enjoy it.The best part of the oreo cupcake was the oreo cookie on top of it. the icing was too hard and the cupcake itself tasted like a normal pound cake that I could make myself. It tasted exactly like ones I had made - the ones that convinced me I wasn't a good baker at all. The fudges were equally as unimpressive. They were dense and floury, and I could hardly taste the white chocolate flavour in the white chocolate fudge. Even the standard chocolate one didn't taste like much. It was just floury. The coconut meringue and raspberry marshmallow were ok, but by that time, I was already too thoroughly disappointed to enjoy them.

xfjED37ZNGut4U2Kw2E8Qw.text: Bea's serves up a lovely cup of coffee and has a fantastic assortment of cakes and pastries as well as some other tempting things like salads. They also brew their own chai which is a nice touch. As with all the premium coffee houses in the area, the coffee is overpriced but they do have an option of a large cup which is something at least. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area, and if you work on that side of Holborn the only alternative is Wild & Woods who don't sell a large cup.

YTw9zu5wMfpAXgmZQIUR0g.text: Had the afternoon tea and the cupcakes were delicious but everything else was just average. There were supposedly three types of sandwiches but two of them were very similar so not very varied. Place is cute but very small with limited table space. The younger waitress was very pleasant but the older one was cold and very curt, definitely a turnoff. Finally a tea service charge was added to the cost of the afternoon tea - this is in addition to the 15% overall service charge!! - which is not mentioned anywhere on their site, seems wrong if they do not mention up front. Would I recommend? Probably not., I think I'd try a different one if the price were similar.

F7VNhbWnFxdUswYt02n0gA.text: If a simple look at the window display here at Bea's doesn't have your sweet tooth throbbing, I don't know what will. Though a smaller selection of tea than in the following reviews, Bea's secret weapon is its scones with clotted crème. But beware, the scones are only available, fresh out of the oven from 2:30PM onward and they go quick.Added Bonus: For the summer months Bea's offered an Afternoon Tea Picnic--by ordering ahead you can have all the yummy goodness of afternoon tea, complete with scones, cupcakes, etc. in a nearby park complete with wicker picnic basket and ceramic plates and tea cups.

qLWgNjgl0fpMNLGwhClVQQ.text: once my favourite, it has gone pretty much downhill over the past year or so.Ever since the coffee machine broke at the Kings Road Branch and they could not make a mocha for many weeks, the place somehow lost its mojo. I had a stale slice of cake the other morning (holborn branch) and staff seems to have changed & great service dissapeared. Also, the afternoon tea used to be under £10 and now it is somewhere around £16. I don't know what happenned to Beas; maybe they just got too big?

q5CtZnA-neK6_aTbIIbZaA.text: thank you thomas for showing me the way. I couldn't BEA anymore of a fan for BEA'S of bloomsbury. (see what i did there?}thomas and I had a full tea there and even though i am trying to diet and say no to sugar I couldn't resist anything that they had there. the cupcakes, and the meringues and the bailey's truffles!!! oh if I ever get struck with diabetes I know that it would be worth it. just talking about it makes me want the cupcakes now.the only complaint i have is that the menu is a little hard to read.. it didn't really make sense, they don't really explain how much it costs and exactly what you are ordering. but I'm sure you could ask more specifics if you want. I just hate looking so cheap.

yTflQjz1sZhcFwul_iMGmA.text: Now that I am sitting here with a beautifully cooked, moist, and generous portion of baked chicken, a lovely fresh tomato, basil and mozzerella salad, and the most superb potato salad ever for a 3.90 takeout price, I give it 5 stars (and not to mention the frittatas looked divine!)

NZdXTfrfCfl9nk4ZvoWT_A.text: Hmmm.  What's better than chocolate?  Double chocolate of course, as in Bea's double chocolate cookies.  Calling them cookies don't even really do them justice, as their nothing like the flimsy, waif thin cookies you might get elsewhere.  These are more like chocolately lumps of goodness.  I know, lump isn't exactly a flattering word but that's the best way I can describe these cookies.  These cookies are thick, you know like.... nevermind.   I also tried a few of their almond madeleines (they had another name I can't remember).  A little crunchier on the outside than your standard madeleine but they grew on me.Definitely would make an effort to stop by again and try some of their cakes next time I find my way to London.

YEKgsCHRLBiYzX4cbtEoBA.text: I went here on Saturday to try the afternoon tea. You need to book a table for this on weekends (maybe one week in advance) because the place is very small and very popular too! We made a reservation for two by e-mail and I got very quick and friendly answers from the staff. The afternoon tea menu consisted of 2 different cupcakes, 2 scones with clotted cream and (I think it was raspberry but it might be strawberry) preserve, 2 mini Valrhona chocolate brownies, 2 mini blondies and 4 mini marshmallows, and of course a pot of tea (blackcurrant and hibiscus for me) or coffee (my boyfriend had a macchiato). Everything was very nice and I think the price is quite good, £9.90, given the quality and the quantity of the food! I loved the place, it's tiny and cosy and you can see the kitchen from the table. It gives you a feeling of really artisan and home made. Yesterday they had cardboard boxes everywhere (I guess because they don't have much storage space in the shop) with packed cupcakes ready to be transported to the Taste of London festival. Some might think that it's a kind of unprofessional detail or whatever like that, but for me, it was just the touch of very small and lovely, special and of indeed successful business. It's a pity that I live rather far from the place and it's very unusual for me to be around that area of London, but if I happend to be near some day I will certainly stop there and buy something. I definitely recommend anyone to try this place.

vbFvCbVDkYgMAa34AIsZ9g.text: Couldn't get a reservation for tea but we came anyway and enjoyed a delicious tea on street side tables. The English tea was the best I've ever had.  The scones with clotted cream were very, very good and the cupcakes (one strawberry, one chocolate) were absolutely delicious. Staff was very pleasant although they were quite busy. Highly recommended!

3mwevSOvcxyxH9T7Je0nhg.text: Bea's is a sweet little bake shop! (No pun intended.) The desserts are amazing, both in taste and appearance; I am eager to come back, just to try everything on the menu. Now I realize why this place is always busy!The menu is definitely a bit pricey, comparable to a high-end bake shop. Do keep in mind, however, that every item is homemade and richly flavored.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Strawberry cupcakes. (If this isn't convincing you to visit, I don't know what is.)

1I9AXHGCMeXAUn1eKzzECQ.text: This was my second visit to Bea's, after being impressed by the yummy carrot cake last year, I bought a friend a voucher for afternoon tea. I really wanted to love Bea's afternoon tea, so I think my expectations may have been a little high. There were six of us for afternoon tea and as other reviewers have said the price is competitive for afternoon tea - £19  per person - which is quite good for a tea in London. It however was not the best. The scones were lovely, the sandwiches OK although we were surprised (we were a greedy group) to find that there were an allocated number per person, as opposed to unlimited sandwiches like at some other tea places. The most disappointing thing about the tea was the lack of cake variety, Bea's offers lots of lovely and delicious cakes, but the tea includes a cupcake and three little squares of chocolate brownie types. The greedy person in me and the cake lover in me hoped for a little more cake variety and maybe one square of brownie and something different would have been nice. So overall Bea's does an OK afternoon tea, it ticks all the tea boxes, but a few small changes may have made it even better.

hZ35Q4BcEygYkKmHmINGGQ.text: Bea's is very cute little place to meet for afternoon tea, although there are some kinks. My friend made a reservation but appeared to have been missed off the list when we arrived. Fortunately there was some outside seating available, although it's not especially comfortable even on a sunny day. The tea was lovely and we shared a selection of their cakes which were brilliant - of particular note was the passion fruit marshmallow and the chocolate and raspberry cupcakes. Another friend ordered a red velvet cupcake and received a free one when the waitress forgot to bring it out which was kind, but most of the staff seemed rather dismissive and distracted. The inside is very small so not ideal on a cold or wet day as it gets very packed. A good place to meet if you're in the area but not especially worth going out of your way for.

vXkKpYmiVpZX9xOcyYOsnw.text: A lovely afternoon tea experience. I called in to book afternoon tea the day-of, a couple hours before I intended to visit. They were very accommodating and took my reservation. The place was clearly busy when I arrived but my table was ready and Hamid was attentive. Everything I tasted was delicious. I particularly enjoyed the sandwiches, which were a nice alternative to the standard white bread finger sandwiches typically served with afternoon tea. The sweets were very delectable. My tea came with a mango cupcake, which I loved even though I rarely like fruit flavored cake. The brownies were wonderful and moist; I may have to revisit just to pick up some brownies. Their dessert case also had other tempting treats which I hope to try at some point. I recommend this afternoon tea spot - tasty food, fun location, good service.

Wq7R20QjKdVh3EwDQF-GuQ.text: It almost seems strange that for not the first time, I've sat down to write reviews and found one of my regular stops on the list that still hasn't been reviewed after living in London for over three months. Beas is one of those stops, a necessary tea and pastry stop in the overwhelmed business school world I now call my life.I love that they offer afternoon tea, that they have sugar bowls on every table.I love the cupcakes, including the blue cookie monster ones on Halloween which dyed my mouth blue.I love the pastries, fluffy and light, or decadent and too-rich-for-breakfast (but perfect for curing a mid-class hangover).I love the Thanksgiving dinner, offering us expats a welcome taste of home with friendly service and a good price.I've obviously celebrated holidays at Beas. I trust them to give me good food when I most miss things from home. The atmosphere is quirky yet so comfortable that I love to pop in. I certainly have no plans of stopping my tea and pastry study breaks and meetings now.

zAd6Ck4-uCtINuRPHIfOnw.text: Now that I'm far away from them, I find myself longing for a passion fruit cupcake... I would even stand in line for a coffee that too far too long to make. Oh Bea's how I miss you and your sweets

Ud8xAw2ruGvzmkTPOv6xtA.text: I contemplated if I should give a rating here as the ONLY reason for them is their red velvet cupcakes. So yelpers... this is a review of their red velvet cupcakes and NOTHING else.Now that we have that out of the way... I can move on to the good part. The red velvet cupcakes (YES!). Since I moved from New York to London, I have been on a quest to find the perfect red velvet. In doing so I have kissed many a frogs (or worse actually), may it be in road side bakeries (which use whipped cream to frost the one cupcake where EVERYTHING is in the frosting!) to the elites like Lola's (decent RV's) and Hummingbird (sadly, a huge disappointment for that one flavor at least). Then, a friend brought us these and even though I had a tiny bite, tears gushed through my eyes. Its not new york, but the soft and mildly sweet cream cheese frosting sits so well with the red colored normal cake! it was a christmas miracle. Therefore we hiked up this place (me and other fellow ex newyorkers suffering from red velvet withdrawals) to get ourselves one! The place is really small and so we couldn't find a seat. Which sucked coz it was cold and wet outside. So if you want to enjoy the cake over a warm cuppa... maybe reserve in advance? Thats also why I gave them a star less (coz the cupcakes get 5 stars), as they are a bit too small for a decent sized cafe. But the cupcakes were great! and I am dreaming of another box that I might soon get (new years diet be damned!)

0wb5LaGjYhpt8601f9rSAg.text: Saw this place on the Travel channel. Only had cupcakes because the place is packed full of people! The cupcakes were good. Tried four different flavors. The food looked really good. Friendly staff and very good service!

3gGGYp1dq8BoyDBVAxE75Q.text: I may or may not have seen Bea's on a travel show, may or may not have happened to pass it on my commute, may or may not have stopped and picked up a box to spoil myself and my co-workers with (but not before spending 20 minutes to pick flavors)........ .....................and may or may not have created a monster...or 10..... The massive and beautiful meringues are on next on my hit-list....waist beware.

JJspv08zJ0QLrqFLUEiTbQ.text: Best scones I have ever tasted.  So much flavor.  It is quite expensive, 2 scones and a pot of tea for 7 pounds but if you want the best, you have to pay for the best.  I don't like the fact where we have to get a table number, why not get the stuff at the counter and then go to any table?  But they can tell me to do anything they want, as long as there are scones in the end

Y2zGANecthJjczr5fLb0Rg.text: This is a nice place for an easy-going-weekday-morning, if this is possible for you! I went to the place two times before I succeeded in trying it. The first time there was no setting option (just take away), since they were painting the walls. So I did not go in :S. The second time, it was a bank holiday, so they were closed. the third time, I cam with full eagerness to try Bea's and I ready did it this time ... Hooray :) The coffee was good, pastries are nice, I was waining for something to surprise me in this place, I was waiting for some good half an hour or so .. and suddenly the cub cakes came to the seen ... Traaaa! so I asked about the cub cakes and it was 'red velvets' .. yummy .. so I ordered one and it was hmmm very good, a bit dry but still very good .. to be honest, I loved the icing more than the cake . So coffee and cake was (very) good and we are almost done. so I was wondering what does people (yelppers) like about this place ??? and suddenly I notice the magic bit of this place ... it's the baking area .. it is just so cute and happening all the time.. they are so busy preparing things from scratch .. so you feel like you are sitting in the kitchen while they are preparing your cake .. such a magical feeling that makes thinking of coming again.. The service was not that good at the beginning, but suddenly they start to smile and to be friendly .. I guess they noticed that I'm trying to check-in (yelp in iphone) :P The place is great, and worth a try!

yyMpaQwPeGwBC2U65FCFEA.text: Well this makes me happy to see, not only did I have a lovely time in Bea's this morning but then I go online and see them all friendly and claiming their business online, how lovely. Poor Thomas W was very unlucky, but I have to say that I didn't try the cupcakes so I can't comment there. They do look beautiful though. I had a breakfast date with Larissa D here this morning before we both headed off to work. So at 8am we wondered in to be greeted by a lovely selection of tea's and some breakfast pastries. We settled on porridge but I think I was sold on the selection of toppings you could choose from, or in Larissa and mine cases, plonk ALL of them on! Cinnamon, sugar, coconut, honey, cold milk, dried fruits and nuts... it was a smorgasbord of delights.As if that wasn't enough they have a whole table (granted it was small! but still) coverd with a toaster, nutella, honey, jam, cream cheese, butter and marmite all ready and waiting to be used. We shared a cheese scone which was so lovely and soft inside and perfectly crumbly outside, I went to the little table with my half, toasted it, butter it and then gobbled it up. They served my favourite type of tea, which was in a pot but not the pretty pots with legs that I saw behind the counter which was a little disappointing. I couldn't leave without trying their coffee so I had a black one and was a little disappointed that it wasn't a filter but no worries as it was quite tasty and smooth. I'd have it again.Over all Bea's wins with me, I went on a quite morning and was greeted by friendly staff, who even let me use their loo (thank you ladies). If I'm in that area again, I shall pop in.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

uYI6WNi995HRVwA8nRnvXQ.text: Lovely tea drinking place - I was lucky to get there on a rainy Sunday afternoon. Cozy tea and moist carrot cake (that can almost compete with mine!) were just what I needed. Although lovely it is not that different from any other tea drinking bakeries I've been to.I didn't like the view of the kitchen at the back, I think it slightly ruins the delicate atmosphere.  Worth checking out not sure about regular check ins!

D7jGGOJ2cVoJbidlb0klvg.text: Lovely tea shop with friendly and attentive staff.  The tea and food were superb.  I mainly enjoyed my tea recommendation and the clotted cream.

05oWX2S0OVy10_AkXEfZxA.text: Oh hello, Bea's of Bloomsbury. Some wonderful colleagues of mine took me here for lunch and described it as "girly." I thought that was a strange description, until I arrived and realized it was very apt. Tea, little cakes, light salads, general adorableness. Definitely girly! They also do a proper high tea, and if I ever find myself in London again, I'll make time for it. I loved this place - everything was delicious and so, so cute. Tea set displays finished off the cute-factor. Maybe I'm a tourist, but WHATEVER! Twas rad, loved it, would go again.

v4OPsxO0ceeG8Lqh8znvXQ.text: Considering that afternoon tea consists of tea and cake, the often exorbitant prices ranging up to £100 and sometimes more, are a little extreme in my opinion - and that's where the delightful Bea's of Bloomsbury comes in. You can get your daytime sugar fix and wash it down with a pot of tea (or a coffee if you wish) for a mere £12 - and you won't be disappointed!I went with my fiancé, and each of our afternoon teas came with a scone (complete with clotted cream and jam), a cupcake (we had one chocolate with pistachio frosting and one vanilla with passion fruit frosting) a mini brownie, a mini blondie, a homemade passionfruit marshmallow, a mini meringue and some other little cakey thing (I can't remember what it was called!) - all yummy!This is a sweet afternoon tea, so no sarnies, and if it all sounds a bit too decadent, then you can go for the half option of just tea and a scone.We loved our afternoon tea - the scone was divine, the brownies were rich and dense, the cupcakes were great flavours and the meringues were crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside. Yum. I am not a fan of marshmallows to begin with, and although this one was interesting in texture (bouncy to the touch!) and more flavourful than the usual kind, it was not really my thing.By the end of our tea I was stuffed! I spent the whole time we were in there admiring all the delicious looking sweets on the counter, and I can honestly say that by the end of it, I couldn't have eaten another thing, no matter how scrumptious it all looked!

HG-SEGkiX9_MPJIQxZaZuA.text: Bea's have got presentation down to a fine art. This is one of the most enticing bakeries I've ever been to, everything looks irresistible, from the muffins, cakes and croissants to the salads and cheesecakes and sandwiches grouped on the counters. They change their menu every day too so when you come back there's always something new to tempt you. I came here for breakfast: a cup of coffee, some porridge and a blueberry muffin. Tasted just like mum's.

hrqNBEpwMR_Ou36DyUT8RQ.text: I took a friend to Bea's today for afternoon tea as my special treat for her birthday. I asked if I needed a reservation and I was told it wasn't necessary, thank goodness we found a table outside as the place was packed with smiling customers devouring cake. The scones were still in the oven when we got there and we waited half an hour for them but it was well worth it! We ordered two coffees in the meantime and then the afternoon tea. The assortment of cakes is amazing and what about those huge passionfruit marshmellows? Fab! It's a shame we had to wait a bit but to be perfectly honest who cares, the sun was shining, the tea was fresh, the cakes even fresher and the company of my friend delightful. I will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

bd9HpeCUbGB2ZwW3jaLe2w.text: I stopped in here with Cassandra H. before a Yelp Event earlier in the week, and had a pot of tea and a small shortbread sandwich cookie.(yes it was a cookie, with cream in the middle and not a tea biscuit, dang it! you leave the american and her wonky words alone!)The tea was fine, great flavour, nice pot set up with a removable filter that let me pull out the tea leaves once they had steeped enough. (and yes, I did set a timer after I saw the gal fill our pot. just a tad obsessive, I am.)it being the last hour of business, I can knock Bea's. The two girls working the counter were still friendly, and even though we stayed til just before close they didn't make us feel rushed. My cookie was shortbread, rich and crumbly.I can't knock Bea's. It seems like it would be a great place to come for an afternoon cuppa with my mum or a friend who's not put off by the more traditional tea house vibe. I will be back during the day to sample some food and have another lovely pot of tea. (and you can bet I will be quizzing my server on what temperature of water they use to prepare the different styles of tea, and where the tea comes from etc. etc.) Expect an update!

g1w5AKqI2LxgJSBf4bvKgA.text: The Chocolate Peanut Butter cupcakes are heaven.Chocolate and peanut butter oh God!They are absolutely one of my favourite ones. I simply feel happier when I come here and eat those. They can make even the worst day feel better. Of course, I should not forget to mention the caramel sauce and the light mascarpone cheese cream frosting. I'll save you the details and let you discover the flavours on your own. You truly are missing a lot if you haven't visited Bloomsbury yet.

8IMetYN2ljrCACj0HqWoMg.text: Friends of mine brought me here for traditional afternoon tea while on a visit to London. Although I don't really have anything to compare it to, I completely enjoyed my experience at this place. We had reservations so we were seated promptly when we walked in by our friendly and smiling waiter.  The tea was great because they had a wide selection and you receive your own tea pot. I had the English tea, while my friends sipped on Earl Grey and Green tea. You can ask for as much cream and sugar as you would like. As for the food, the scones with clotted cream were delicious, as were the mini sandwiches which included a variety between beef, turkey and tomato with mozzarella. I was so stuffed from those that we all took our cupcakes for take away, so we could eat them later. We also had some brownie bites, vanilla marshmallows and meringue. All were delicious and satisfying. The complete experience cost about 18 pounds. If you're ever in London and want some traditional afternoon tea, I would definitely recommend calling here to make a reservation!. However, there seemed to be plenty of open seats on the Wednesday afternoon that we stopped by, so you could also take your chances.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea!

dsf2F-aTZByRn83XhVRUgw.text: This is a review of the wedding consultation service. It took a few tries to get an appointment. I initially tried calling the St.Paul's branch to get a consultation there (It's far easier for me to get to than the bloomsbury branch).On the phone I was told that I needed to book a normal table and call them later. Luckily I didn't do this. I couldn't make the day I was originally looking at, so I instead called their events booking line.I was told the computer system was located in the office and that there was a meeting going on. I asked when I should call back and was told 'I don't know, try again in 20 minutes'. I called back 20 minutes later and was told that the meeting was still going on and to call back in half an hour.I did that and was told the computer system was down. So far, not a great experience.I ended up waiting a few days to call again. When I did I was told that the lady I needed to talk to was out of the office and I should call back later. Great.I finally after all this managed to speak to someone. I asked to have my consultation at St. Paul's and was told that they don't do consultations at St. Paul's, only at Bloomsbury. Which is fine. Just extremely annoying considering no one up to this point had mentioned that. Not even the staff at St Paul's.I finally managed to book in an appointment, and made my way to Bloomsbury. Man, I'm glad I did!They were extremely helpful, talking me through all the different types of cakes and finishes. They spent a good hour/hour and a half with my fiancé and me.The end result of this is that I ordered my wedding cake from them. I love Bea's, and couldn't be happier that they are doing my cake. We got to try all the different flavours and discussed details I hadn't even thought of. They were extremely knowledgable and put me instantly at ease.If it wasn't for the multiple phone calls and issues booking in the first place, this would have been an instant 5* review. I was toying with 3*s because it really left a bad taste in my mouth even before I'd arrived. However, the stellar service they gave us pulled it back up to a 4.If you're planning on having a wedding cake, or any other special occasion I recommend Bea's. Just call the Bloomsbury store straight away.

EPpLyJ7zpSmsSBU_CYat_g.text: I absolutely love this place ! I discovered it a few years ago when I was on holidays in London. I had spotted it in a blog (a little Internet research about where to eat is always helpful) and I really wanted to go. I remember a very long walk down the road to find the place, I was actually quite tired but I didn't want to give up, I nearly missed it because it's very small but it was really worth the efforts ! The cupcakes were truly gorgeous. I have tried quite a few places and sometimes I find that cupcakes can be quite "heavy" in your stomach, too "rich", too sugary but the ones in Bea's are just perfect, really tasty but light ! The staff is really nice and helpful. There's another Bea's near St Paul's, which might be handier in terms of location. I went there last year and I loved it too.

k_WmODBym3CHbh8FwWd1sA.text: I came to Bea's of Bloomsbury for afternoon tea with a friend.  Reservations are a must as it gets packed on the weekends especially.  It is an adorable little bakery that is a feast for the eyes to see upon entrance, with all of the cupcakes, scones, and muffins on display.  We ordered the classic afternoon tea set that came with a pot of tea, finger sandwiches full of clotted cream, mozzarella, and parma ham, then deliciously fresh scones, brownie bits, meringue, and cupcakes for each person.  The service was fast and yet they did not rush us at all to eat, as we were chatting wonderfully about the past week.  The staff is lovely! They even personalized a cupcake for my friend who was celebrating her birthday.I am telling all my friends to come visit this place before they leave London as it is a very vintage high tea experience.

yJuPt-Y16YKDZZkMycy-Yw.text: Went to Bea's yesterday at 5 for afternoon tea. We arrived 10 minutes early and table was ready. We sat in a cozy corner. I was really excited about enjoying a proper British afternoon tea, but first of all the tea that was brought to me was totally subpar. I ordered the vanilla black. It came in barely hot water so it took for ever for the tea to take any  flavor and colour. I get this is a cafe and that's why you cannot expect attentive service, I guess. The sandwiches that came with the afternoon tea were not good. If I ever went back I would only get the scones and clotted cream. They were very good!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

H6mgAyy-Ffn-6qmNUjkNgw.text: Very good place, nice decoration and atmosphere, great cupcakes !!I had a chocolate and raspberry cupcake and a small fruit salad bowl.Everything was very tasty,the cupcake seemed very light.The two things cost 6£

UTNWE0i_v5T3iHd72UVesg.text: They said they were doing us a favor by squeezing us in with only a 45min window...then gave us no menu and told us we had to buy by the piece. Very generous (heavy sarcasm). Then they broke a three tier tray with another persons pastries right next us & we were showered with broken glass and powdered sugar. Only in Europe do they not only not apologize or comp you for such a wretched experience.

QDfLHuRjE5MZpbp4vbltMA.text: This place is incredible. Amazing service and best scones I've had in my life. Everything we tried there was incredible. One cannot go wrong with Bea's.

Lvf8kpvTEfa-ETVTTSAtbg.text: Items ordered:Earl Grey SupremeStrawberries and Cream CupcakeScones with Clotted Cream and JamBrownie Bite, Walnut Brownie Bite, Blondie Bite, Strawberry Meringue, Vanilla MarshmallowPB&J SliceCarrot BreadJammie Cookie CupcakeRed Velvet CupcakeFollowing a proper Sunday Roast another goal for my trip to London was a suitable spot for cream tea and not particularly sold on pricey finger sandwiches in the refined environs of five-star hotels I turned to Bea's of Bloomsbury - their offering of a dessert forward "Sweet Tea" service far more my speed.  Apparently now an expanding commodity with three small shops throughout the British capitol it was without reservations that I entered the Theobalds Road flagship and although packed on arrival it was a matter moments before a table up front opened up - my boxed to-go order soon joined by a £12 septet served alongside steeping Earl Grey Supreme.  Every bit a cutesy café with servers bustling to and fro while a team of bakers brought new treats forth from the kitchen in back it was with little debate that my tasting began with Bea's warm scone and although a bit more crumbly than other scones to follow the combination of thick sweetened cream and freshly made jam made the point moot - a similar effect achieved by the hefty dollop of cooked frosting and plump strawberries atop a cupcake whose base proved a touch dry.  Admittedly a bit uninspired by my first few bites it was onward to small treats that I progressed and although somewhat lacking in diversity the results were quite nice as all three brownies proved quite rich while meringue and marshmallow were expectedly light.  At this point taking my tasting to the streets it was in part that evening and then the next day that I continued my Bea's experience and perhaps as a result of selections or maybe just a matter of time each of the remaining selections would prove better than anything I tasted in-house, both cupcakes well balanced and quite moist while carrot bread and a cake seemingly made of nothing but pureed peanuts and thick jam beneath buttery streusel rivaled similar versions back home.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Scones with Clotted Cream and Jam

Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Strawberries and Cream Cupcake, Scones, Treats = Cream Tea

9Ng91J3TG-Qrvvdltu-WXw.text: I'm actually addicted to the banana bread and cupcakes from Bea's. Great salad, sandwich and quiche selection for lunch, not to mention that they have over 10 kinds of cupcakes to choose from everyday. The cakes are SO moist, rich but not too dense - so delicious! Afternoon tea here may not be the best in London, but it's such a good deal for what you're paying. You get a good selection of cupcakes, blondies, scones etc - definitely book in advance because it always fills up!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

8D3trCaIrh8f9JGzrHhvDg.text: As is so often the case, I was left in charge of arranging something to do with my group of girlfriends. My past successful choices have made me the choice person to select where we go on our meetups. I've typically opted for decent, inexpensive food with a good cocktail menu. This time, however, one of the group has a bun in the oven. My usual recipe for success was not going to work. I ummed and arred about what to do and then thought of afternoon tea. 'Excellent' I thought, until I saw that many of the London spots charge £50 a head. Way out of our budget.Then I found Bea's of Bloomsbury. Very well regarded across the internet, consistently in Top 10 Afternoon Tea lists and excellent value to boot.I book via their website a few days before we wanted to go. I was worried I'd left it to late but it's was incredibly simple. In the time between booking, confirming and getting there are numbers had dwindled but the staff were absolutely fine with it.I really should get onto the afternoon tea though. I should have told you already, but this was my first ever afternoon tea (in 28 years, how is that possible?). I ordered a pot of Vanilla Black and shortly after our cake stand arrived, overflowing with beautifully presented sandwiches, cakes and sweet treats. I was shocked by just how much the three of us would be eating: 3 mini sandwiches, a scone with clotted cream and strawberry jam, 3 types of brownies, muffins, meringues and marshmallows. EACH!Bea's really is not only excellent value for money but excellent full stop. I will go again (and again and again)

1v1EpsZ1gFgCuj06HlGrLA.text: Simply the best place for tea. I know I am a guy but living in London with fiance makes me need to get tea (if I can plan my own golf and ski trips and not get grief). Anyway the cream tea is all anyone really needs. The full tea can be split between two or among three. Just depends what sweets you want. Crumpets are perfect and I always enjoy earl gray. The girls liked the sweets but they are overpowering.

7Zqv3oX2nH8HkKLnJSDvRg.text: Love this little shop in Bloomsbury! Stopped by this morning for a quick coffee on the way to work, and they had an excellent pastry deal. Super friendly staff and a well nice cup of coffee too. My husband and i have been before close to their closing time, and they were happy to sit and chat with us for a bit. Lovely ambiance, lovely staff, lovely food. Looking forward to taking some American friends here for a proper Afternoon Tea soon!

ozPeokIM0hBYOplvy4nUUw.text: Now this is my kinda afternoon tea, hold the savoury and double, nay triple up on the sweetnessFor £12 per person you get a choice of tea served in a lovely pot and a wide selection of cakes - a cupcake, scone, homemade marshmallow, brownie, blondie, meringue....If you do however manage to finish the whole selection then you're a better person than me!  I always ask for a takeaway box and stash the rest for later... think of it as a double servingIt's small, cute and the serving plates are amazingHowever the kitchen at the back is open which isn't particularly glamorous and the toilets smell a bit musty.  The service is laid back and quite hard to grab attention, but generally friendly.I would definitely recommend if for nothing else than a wander around a Bloomsbury and onto the British Museum (where afternoon tea is over £30 per person by the way)

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

jEzBxhN6Q1BwnNTut8bQ9g.text: Husband brings home treats from Bea's and they have the most amazing cupcakes I've ever tasted - incredibly creamy icing and dense, moist cake. My husband loves the coffee, too and says service is great. I had to write a review to give this place it's well deserved recommendation.

KqYmUNkAwqsLXCzGB8ZPdA.text: The price was fine (relatively) for an afternoon tea, and a few of the treats were downright scrumptious (YES passionfruit marshmallow but not so much on the dry brownies and blondies)... but whoa! what's going on with the service here? It's enough to bring the whole experience down.Considering the place was only about half full (and the upstairs area only about 10 tables to begin with), tea service was achingly slow. Nevermind how long it SHOULD take to bring out a pre-assembled tray of nibbles (random thought: it would have also been nice to specify the flavor of Bea's creative cupcakes rather than being given two at random, no rhyme or reason per table)... I assume the intention was to stagger the treats a bit after we've had time to savor and sip the tea. But how long does water take to boil? The tea itself didn't come until over 30 minutes after we ordered it, and despite the fact that the waiter wasn't doing much only 10 steps away, he never came over to let us know what was going on. Perhaps he had no concept of time?

N7oKIs91U4FycVll7xpAlg.text: My first afternoon tea experience in London took place here.  Now, I actually have had tea in New York, so I had some experience for comparison.  For 19 pounds, you get sandwiches, raspberry marshmallows, blondies, brownies, cupcakes, scones, and of course tea!  Compared to many places in London, this place will get your money's worth. Now why only the three stars?  The sandwich bread.  While flavorful, these pieces of bread were so difficult to chew on.  I almost felt like I was breaking my teeth, and my friends even dipped their sandwiches in their tea just to soften them up.  The desserts were great though.  Scones are always hard to get right, but this place had it right--moist and scrumptious with jam and clotted cream.In terms of atmosphere, it was just an ordinary cute bake shop without a view.  We did have comfy cute pillows though.

lKSHE5WuEurxAt3NUmkKpA.text: Came here after walking by and being sucked in by the window display of cupcakes. I opted not to get a cupcake (though they looked scrumptious and delicious), but instead chose to get the mango passionfruit cheesecake. It was amazingly delicious and satisfied my sweet tooth =)

2MakARd17yjJ5YhRd69rBQ.text: One of the only place where I experienced not-so-good service. Really.. Is it because I am a man or a visitor ? Don't know, but even it was quiet on that morning, I didn't feel it is a place I can stay for a long time.Very girly and beautiful counter, my eyes were catch by so many beautiful cakes. After a certain time, i go for the carrot cake (of course!). It was delicious, I even wanted to order it a second time. In perfect combination with their cappuccino, at £2.6, it is a competitive price. But I would recommend to choose tea instead.Opening hours are large, but they open at 10am on Saturday. The kitchen is located at the back, everything is produced locally.

0KCwewaYwnq9HbXtMMDVfQ.text: Cream. tea.You're not going to get a lovely, intimate tea room setting, but you WILL get the most delicious, buttery scones EVER that go perfectly with clotted cream and jam. I honestly don't remember what tea I ordered, but it doesn't matter. Come for the scones, and be deliriously happy.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

1aaXY_KoifwtWyeBAKYmBQ.text: My all time favourite cup cake shop, they have a few branches across London so every time I walk past one, I can't resist. Some of my favourites include peanut butter which just melts in your mouth and it's better than reese (trust me!) and ofcourse the classic red velvet. I like the fact that's it's not too heavy as some cup cakes can be and he icing isn't too thick. Definitely go to the bigger shops like near Kings cross or in St Pauls to devour their big cake slices with a lovely selection of tea.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

cMvkElGYU3G6jjOPDOE0BA.text: This is the perfect spot for a short tea break if you don't have enough time for a full blown sit down champagne afternoon tea.  I've been told the desserts here are excellent but I love the tea and scones in particular.  Lather up the scones with silky smooth Devonshire cream and raspberry preserves and you're in for a delicious experience.Wasn't too fond of the service; however, hence the deduction of a star.

Q_d5nxEue1CQCEfJLyHChQ.text: This cute bakery was getting ready to shut down but we had 20 min to enjoy the sumptuous scones and tea. I wish we had come earlier as this little cafe was charming with nice staff. Nothing is better than scones with clotted cream and jam. We split a lot of tea since we were short on time but it was plenty. Also try the Guiness cake, delicious!

0H9i2sNBQpnSOS74p2udIw.text: This was on my trek home from University to my flat. I stopped in for a scone and tea once in a while and of course everything is delicious but it is so SO expensive. When my parents came to visit we got the scone tea. The amount of sweets on it is insane and I loved every bit of it. Will never forget the memories I had here.

oOwBtWR-X0aomyN8cMIeQA.text: Before coming to London, afternoon tea was probably the thing I was most excited about (that's normal, right?). So a couple friends and I went on Yelp one night, looked up afternoon tea places, and came across this one that seemed pretty highly rated. The pictures and website looked promising enough, so we made a reservation online and visited the next day.The afternoon tea menu is pretty simple - I believe you're given three options that only differ by the inclusion of "extra" drinks. I went with the basic option and ordered green tea. The food (on the stereotypically cute tower) came out relatively quickly, and at first glance I thought "ok, this is a reasonable amount of food." But then 5 minutes later ANOTHER plate came out - this time with our sandwiches. And holy, these sandwiches are NOT your traditional "high tea" sandwiches with thin white bread. These were EXTREMELY bread-heavy sandwiches (that were not cute at all...besides the point, but still worth mentioning).I decided to try a sandwich first - big mistake. The bread was super salty and since it was so thick I also started feeling pretty full. But then we still had the tower of sweets. I tried the marshmallow next - pretty good. I wasn't a fan of the meringue, and I definitely wasn't a fan of the brownies, which I thought were too hard and one of which tasted like Snickers...I didn't really like the cupcakes either - the texture of the frosting was a bit off and the cake part didn't taste that great either.The redeeming points of this place, in my opinion, are the scones and the service. The scones were by far my favorite, especially paired with the jam (didn't really fancy the clotted cream). Oh, and the tea was pretty good too. I also really appreciated the service - the staff was so kind and definitely made our experience much better than it would have just based on the food.Will I be back? Probably not. For 27 pounds per person, I'd like to get more than just good scones and service. (The place/setting/decor IS pretty cute though, I'll admit.)

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Sandwiches
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon Tea Tower

enpMXt7EENnqNlkOWBQAMQ.text: Duf*fin(duffin)Noun:1. A muffin combined with a doughnut.2. A receptacle of deliciousness, filled with jam or nutella3. A reason to get up in the morningAll the pastries at Bea's are delicious, and they're served with a friendly smile.  Grab your coffee and pastry here or take it to go and sit in Russell Square.  Just be warned - the further you get from the shop, the longer it will be until you can eat one of their treats again.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Duffin delight

rM7NMFXg5htuKItogOHvbg.text: If I'm not mistaken there are 3 (?) locations of Bea's.  But worry not, Bea is not spreading herself too thin...more quality Bea's for all!I'm a big fan of this bakery along Theobalds Road, which could easily be passed by as the buses whizz and people stomp around carrying their Pret bags during harried lunch hours.  Bea's in a bit of a calm port in that storm.  Step in and you see a wide array of cakes available.  Props to the selection: a PB&J bar that makes my US palate weep with joy, lemon slice, "killer" (sounds ominous...ly delicious!) brownie, sweet buns and an interesting creation called the "Duffin".  MOVE OVER, CRONUT, THERE'S A NEW DONUT-HYBRID IN TOWN!  Pillowy and soft, with filling of jam or choco-hazelnut...this is the sweet marriage of donut and muffin.  So, basically, a *totally legit breakfast option*.My friends have gone here for full cream teas, but this is second-hand information as I have never attended.  That said, the reviews have all been stellar: pillowy savoury sandwiches, delicious scones with jam, and delightful presentation.  Completely reasonably priced as well.What I'd like to call out in particular is the range of coffee and tea options.  Specifically, I think their chai latte deserves a special head-nod of acknowledgment.  It's "homemade" (here I assume it refers to the spice blend) and is not syrupy...it brings some significant heat and warmth through the unique spicing.  It's not heavy, or sweet...chai it, you'll like it (BAD PUNNING).The space isn't big for sitting in at this location, but the staff is a treat.  Lovely, helpful, accommodating.Yelp note: scones not always available because...they sell out fast.  Hasten scone-wards!

3QuP44-K5C472HwKNdvyyQ.text: They have several different locations but I went to the café in Marylebone (Devonshire Street); for some reason I couldn't find it listed, so I'll leave my review here instead.We were greeted at first by a lovely and smiling waitress who took our order and asked us to find any table available. The empty ones at the front were bigger, seating four people, so I walked to the back in order to find a table for two as I didn't want to occupy a table meant for a larger group. Another young lady (maybe the manager as she wasn't wearing an apron) came to us (a bit too frantically and we noticed it) and told me we couldn't seat there as the table was already booked, then suddenly looked surprised and asked "oh, is it for you?". Well, if she didn't know WHO had booked the table then it would be less rude to ask first or just lead us to an available one. There was no "reserved" card on that table either, so there was no way I should know. Was there anything on me that made me look like I couldn't possibly have booked that table? Just odd. There were lots of cupcakes but only 3 flavours of cakes (two of them chocolate). The tea was lovely, my friend doesn't like chocolate so she ordered a huge meringue and it was also tasty. But the blondie I had, the main reason for my visit, was a disappointment. I expect a blondie to be moist, soft and a bit gooey in the middle, but this one was totally dry and quite hard. It wasn't that late in the day to justify it being stale. I ate it as I didn't want to kick up a fuss after that not so warm welcome, but I wasn't impressed at all. For the price and the small size I expected a really nice slice of cake but got a tiny brick instead. The same strange lady kept removing the plates from our table as soon as the food had finished. To me it's only polite to wait a minute or so before approaching the table with a smile and ask if we had finished, if we wanted something else, etc. The plates were just swept away without a word or smile. In my case I was still chewing the last forkful (ok, admittedly with that though blondie I had to chew for a while). I felt my presence was somehow unwanted and felt rushed to leave, what I did promptly with no intention to return. My blondie sucked, I didn't try the cupcakes and maybe the rest of the food is good, but they need to work on that attitude.

bOPyWTbs1xA5Co_zpH2RbQ.text: I came here for afternoon tea with my best friend and we both had a great time. Staff was very helpful and friendly and the atmosphere was cozy and cheerful. As for the tea, scones, sandwiches, and pastries, they were to die for! Absolutely delicious. Afternoon tea was a bit pricy, but definitely worth it. Would come here again!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Delicious afternoon tea.

SfbeUzlsKj4IxT9qzSG6Zw.text: Went in for tea when a rain storm came out of no where on a very nice May late afternoon! The food and cakes looked nice but I didn't order anything as I had just eaten, but it  was Mother's Day and as I was leaving the very nice woman who worked there gave me two cupcakes!

iBsyo2EIDQtYSh1l_gSCNQ.text: It's the best cake I ever had in london .. Can't explain how it's really delicious ..I love it .. I had my mocha and ordered for duffin  strawberry ., it's my first time to eat this duffin ..and I'll always visit this shop when i am in london., they have many selections of cup cakes and macaroons , scones and other pastries  looks great .. Staff are friendly ,cool and lovely .. I really like to enter a shop and the staff are smiling .. Don't miss this awesome shop
