bbEbIKQBrdCznrVPz-FFkQ.text: A perfect way to end our London trip on the way to the train station.  The morning crowd had passed, which allowed for a relaxed experience in a quiet space.  We ate way too much, but that's ok, we were on vacation!The PB&J slice was the best of the best.  Unique, perfect balance of peanut butter richness and sweet fruit, and a unique crumbly texture.  This was paired with a raspberry puffin and followed by the best scone and clotted cream I've ever had.  In typical american fashion, each of us had a glass of ice cold milk as well.  All this and the staff was very pleasant.  Couldn't have asked for a nicer experience.

XgtFXPOlQDGM1vue423coA.text: Oh my god!!! Nutella cupcake, raspberry cupcakes, double chocolate cupcakes and I could go on... There are about 20 different types of cupcakes in this tiny little shop just accross from the station! I of course had to stop to taste the nutella one... Oh my god!! Describes it perfectly!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

2HnSFB6QqamgIFH5gZFwYA.text: Was very disappointed. Saw a blurb on-line stating, "The nice folk at Bea's of Bloomsbury have created an afternoon tea especially designed for coeliacs." So my gluten-free fiancé and I took two buses over to Bae's to have our London Tea experience only to arrive and find out they only had one gluten-free cupcake. It was a lovely shop, and quite cute...but not for the wheat intolerant.

hEJVNBAEM1uDmgvOztrhiw.text: So whilst beas are known for their cakes and believe me they are good, for me it's all about the coffee. The coffee is square mile and is always delicious. Usually stop by on the way to work, as there aren't many tables and usually gets really busy later in the day.If you stop by, be sure to check out the cheesecake, the peanut butter cheesecake is like something of dreams. At almost 5 pounds, it may seem a little pricey for a snack, but it's worth every penny. Quite simple some of the best cheesecake I've tasted in the UK. Worth a visit if you're in the area, but be prepared to wait if you go around lunchtime.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Peanut butter cheesecake

PlH9MRV1u-L48yg5vRziPA.text: Went for high tea on a super hot day. BAD idea. Terrible idea. Not only was it terribly sweltering hot but they had ran out of ice so no cold drinks were available for awhile. The sandwiches were ok, big and not the usual ones on flat bread but thicker bread. Just so much bread! The tea was nice, the drinks were nice, the staff were friendly. The deserts were not memorable. Decent for the price.

sPvDdIqupVIWSObfhgZLEg.text: I saw in one of my London guidebooks that this was THE place to come for afternoon tea, so I made a reservation and headed here to this helpful website to see what I was getting into. I almost got a little nervous when I saw some of the reviews, but Bea's held up to all the hype. Other Yelp-ers complained about the service being slow. I visited this shop on a busy Saturday afternoon and my service was great. Friendly, young, smiling faces sat me at my table, took my order, and checked up on me several times. If they were slow in serving me I didn't notice because I was so relaxed in their quaint little shop. I saw other Yelp-ers give less stars because of their food. I was honestly very impressed with everything I was served. Moist blondies and brownies. Delicious homemade marshmallows and meringues. The cupcake was so moist, but I didn't care for the frosting (I'm not much of a frosting person anyways, so take that with a grain of salt). And let me talk about their scones for a second. The best scone I've ever had and the clotted cream and preserves made that thing practically sinful. I also got three savoury finger sandwiches, which were very tasty as well. And my pot of english breakfast was perfection.Overall great spot for tea. For all that you get (5 treats, a cupcake, a scone, 3 sandwiches, and a pot of tea), £19 is a good price. I'll be back for sure.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Full afternoon tea for one.

mpPlOxwGUw059ouesLqD3A.text: I came to Bea's for afternoon tea having read reviews on blogs and yelp. I wish I hadn't! It was disappointing.I was given a really dirty plate, which grossed me out from the jump! I asked the girl behind the counter if I could have another, because mine was dirty. She grabbed it from me and shoved me another one, seeming annoyed! No apology. At least give a fake apology?! I should have walked out then....but I wanted to give them the benefit of the doubt. The tea sandwiches were ho hum. All three were made with the exact same bread, which was lame. One of them basically just had cream cheese smeared onto it.The desserts weren't good. The mini fudge/brownie was stale. The marshmallow is just a marshmallow. The chocolate and peanut butter cupcake was alright.Charging 26 pounds for this afternoon tea is highway robbery.P.S. If my arm was twisted, I would get a scone and tea. But hope to never go back. Sorry to say!

P_TcOEjVtqUUKpl0SaM98g.text: Yummy cakes and tea in a very relaxed, informal environment. The only downside for me were the prices, a bit on the high end. You pay 9 pounds for two scones with clotted cream and jam, plus a cup of tea. For 16 pounds if you can add 4 more items, chosen from brownies, cupcakes etc Everything is good but, if you ask me, not worth a trip from the other side of the city. Still, thumbs up.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

nN5NdfBqUY-7h6oI2eDzlQ.text: My daughter and I came here for afternoon tea because they offered a gluten free option (thank you daughter for finding this place).  The presentation and service were wonderful and when I complemented the cupcake they said they would also send one home with me, which they did!  The bread on the sandwiches could have been fresher but all of the sweets were delicious and the tea was fantastic.  And the Price was considerably less than other places in London.  We enjoyed this experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. High tea, wheat free!

Sl3YA2A8Hp0JeKoP2xqHKA.text: Chose this place after shopping online for a reasonably priced tea that was well reviewed.  Was pretty disappointed, if I'm honest.  None of the food was as good as described.  Tea sandwiches were a bit stale.  Scones were too dense; had the quality of a muffin more than a proper scone.  The little finger pastries were all quite nice (the macaron was probably the best) but didn't wow me.And the ambiance was just awful.  The proprietors were rushed, didn't take any time to make it a special experience, and were blasting 80's rock music the entire time I was there.  Afternoon tea set to Bon Jovi is something I won't soon forget.While I got a good deal (about $30USD), it frankly wasn't worth it.  The afternoon tea at my tea house back home in the US is better by far.

EeHtsloVhx3GKbds_FMfgg.text: Well wasn't this just a quaint little experience for all of us. We got to have ourselves a proper tea and we got to... what else did we get to do? I guess we had a pleasant experience with the food as well. But that is none of your business. Hot chocolate was oh so delicious and just cute. I very much enjoyed it and wish that I could drink significantly more milk in one sitting without throwing up. Well, there's that for you... get it.Tomato soup was very good and paired well with my Croissant with avocado on it. It isn't something to eat by itself it needs sustenance with it (some type of bread) in order to fill you up but the flavor is delightful.THE VERDICT:Everything I had I enjoyed and I believe that there are numerous locations so you should be able to find one or maybe even look for a more proper tea. Expect to drop some dough though, this place isn't inexpensive but it is totally worth the tea experience that I think everyone visiting London should enjoy once... let me repeat, once. Somewhere between a 3.5 and 4.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. classy fun good
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. also good.
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Tomato soup... good.

S8MpwrmUqc166Xel8XGuug.text: Reservations are required for afternoon tea! The GF really wanted to try afternoon tea in the UK and while there are definitely tons of options, Bea's is one of the cheaper "multi-level" afternoon tea places. For about $USD, we got to choose a tea, and tons of snacks. The tea is so-so. Packaging looked like it came from a store. Bea's is one of the more affordable places. I loved their savory snacks such as the sandwiches the best, but the bread and jams were not as good. Scones were a little too dry for my taste. This is ALOT of food. We saved the sweets for last and didn't even get to eat the whole thing since I was completely full!One gripe: After a while, they had to take away our multilevel snack shelf dish so they could prep afternoon tea for another party. Overall 4 stars. This kept the GF occupied for a couple hours.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Food
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Food
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Savory salmon sandwich

YFvEEfQ5TV5oyLId87GlEw.text: I would come here again based on how cute it is!  While in London the bf and I wanted to make sure to have afternoon tea at some point and this place was decently close to our hotel at a reasonable price.  Also note a reservation is required for tea. The tea itself was standard. I got earl grey while the bf got some sort of fruity one. The real standout for me were the scones. They were delicious!!! I also enjoyed the sandwiches. They were a little different since they were on mini brioche buns but quite delicious nonetheless. By the time we got to the sweets we were both pretty stuffed. I didn't get to eat too much of the cupcakes but I was shocked to be so full. It was a great experience and the inside was so nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Cakes in the window
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Tea spread!

sDFphp3oLalint6b04NRuw.text: We came here for our first Afternoon Tea experience in London and the service was great! I very easily made a reservation for 4 30 minutes before the time I wanted and when we arrived, the table was set up for us. Our server was kind and explained to us how Afternoon Tea works. One tower is for 2 people and 1 person is £25. We ordered 2 towers for 4 people and had plenty of food leftover. A tower comes with a savory level, a scone level, and a dessert level. I personally did not care for the savory level. The sandwiches were either too bland or they just were nothing special. The scones were delicious since they were homemade. A lot of the desserts were also not spectacular but just ok.The teas on the other hand were great. I loved the berry tea and had 2 pots of that while sitting there.Overall, I enjoyed the experience I had here, but would not come back as the food was nothing memorable. It's a great one time thing to do if you're in the area!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

s0pltUVTAHJ5sSLQ1bSQZA.text: We had afternoon tea here and it was fantastic! I felt like my childhood tea party dreams were coming true. Every item on the tea trays were delicious and beautifully prepared. The tea was tasty and the waiters were fun and friendly. Unfortunately we had eaten breakfast only an hour and half before so we filled up quickly. I wish we were able to take some home with us. Absolutely amazing and definitely want to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

YSVZBx8x4Wb2xROyA5ULYA.text: We LOVE Bea's. Their scones are AMAZING and their customer service is equally AMAZING. We got to Bea's around 9am. We ordered scones and pot of tea. It was perfection.

DpLq72qJwxydRAO_tVukEw.text: I am not gonna lie, afternoon tea is super pricey for what you get but an experience that everyone should do once if they tryna be bougie. I came here with two other friends and we all paid about 30 pounds each which is pretty damn expensive. Much more sweet pastries than savory ones but still tasted really good! It's definitely way too much dessert but hey you can always take it home right? The staff was friendly and we get unlimited tea which is nice.

S9XIM9nrB1QFeH9nr2f3Hw.text: DELICIOUS afternoon tea! We splurged a bit for the Easter special including some bubbly. The scone (middle layer) and sweets (top layer) were our favorites. Definitely need to pace yourself while making your way through this tower. We each got our own pot of tea and then a takeaway flat white. Refills included.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

SQbEI2LVlw2ETr2HkOj2mQ.text: I scheduled an afternoon tea at Beas of Bloomsbury a few weeks ago when a friend was in town.  I was looking for something cute, but more affordable than the fancy hotels like the Ritz.  I had been to Beas before for a coffee and a scone and to sit and work on some writing.  Suffice to say that they limit your seating time if you aren't there for an afternoon tea, so I was looking forward to this experience.Unfortunately the tea just didn't live up to my expectations.  While the sandwiches were interesting blends of flavours (fig and mascarpone for example) - not usual for afternoon tea, but common flavour combinations, the bread (brioche) on which they were served was dried out.  it seemed to be the sandwiches were prepared the night or longer before and just kept refrigerated.  Lame.The scone was good as I remembered, but not life changing.The cupcakes - I love cupcakes - were the desert.  Again maybe not your stereotypical tea dessert, but I was looking forward to them anyway.  Again flavour combinations were interesting - like coffee. However, I found the flavours to really fall flat.  I was looking forward to a more dynamic taste and again I found the cupcakes to be dry.  I do have high expectations, but I didn't even finish the cupcakes. I'm always a little annoyed when I spend money on something I could have made better at home.I wouldn't return and would recommend trying someplace else.

GSzyMOwJC9mWz5gOqK_yeQ.text: Great afternoon tea spot. The scones are incredible,the staff is friendly, and the ambiance is inviting. I'd recommend it to anyone in the area.

rpDLi_cCuMg4Hd-Ed0ZlpQ.text: Best hot drinks in the neighborhood! Chai latte, coffees, ... are great and much more a personal service versus Neto or pret a manger! Sometimes they do offer their great bakery and sweet range , which are delicious !Cost place and perfect spot to be for having a coffee or the time !

CRO8VFCpPyv4zsKS5Y44gg.text: After doing some research on a traveler budget-friendly afternoon tea experience, I ended up at Bea's of Bloomsbury on a solo trip to London earlier this year. The online booking process through their website was relatively quick, and I was easily able to make a reservation for the next afternoon.When I arrived, I was greeted by two friendly employees who jokingly commented on my reservation for 1 ("We don't often see people come in to eat on their own, but we think that it's great!") while simultaneously making me feel right at home. My table had already been set up prior, and they wasted no time in bringing my tower of savory and sweet treats (I opted for the £24.50 Full Afternoon tea) as well as taking my tea order (I chose a classic English Breakfast). The desserts were delicious - especially the red velvet cupcake - and I particularly enjoyed the parma ham, mascarpone cream, honey and fig relish brioche, which provided a perfectly balanced combination of sweet and salty in each bite. However, my overwhelming favorite was the scone, which had just the right amount of crumble paired with a soft, buttery inside. I am (not so secretly) in love with clotted cream, and the trifecta of carbs + cream + raspberry preserves was just so satisfying. Unfortunately, my stomach wasn't quite large enough to finish everything in one sitting, but the staff was kind enough to box up my leftover desserts (+ some extra clotted cream on my request), which I happily finished for breakfast the next morning. The next time that I find myself in London, I would absolutely make a return visit to Bea's to try some of their other desserts (and snag a couple more of those scones!).

bTbrMUWej9Tk4aLyRjQr9g.text: Super friendly staff available to explain meal deals and pastry offerings such as the phenomenon known as the "duffin," a donut-muffin hybrid, baked not fried, and filled with jelly or nutella. Espresso-based drinks are amazing, and in the morning, you can get a hot drink with a duffin or cinnamon roll for about £2.80, which is totally worth it since the pastries are £2.50. Check out their other offerings from boxed macarons, their famous cupcakes topped with perfectly piped frosting, or cake slices such as Chocolate Guinness Loaf topped with rich creamy frosting. Interior is adorable and they also have afternoon tea offerings. A must-return to try all their hot drinks as well as rotating pastries and cupcake medleys.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Guinness cake on left
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Brownies
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Window

oaV1W1U28LcJebVLAilbiA.text: I stopped by this adorable little bakery because I got lost on the way back to my apartment and needed wifi for google maps. It turns out Bea's is not only aesthetic and has delicious baked goods, the owners are also unbelievably nice. They gave me 4 free cupcakes and offered to help me find my way; it was such a heart warming experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

HcU-64Xx9qf0tgud5zwxYA.text: On my Tuesday rainy morning adventures I came into Bea's with great expectations of scones, clotted cream and jam and they absolutely delivered. Very cute place and would definitely come back for High Tea some time when I'm back in the UK

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

dMg8dvZhWShpeUMVdHRyNA.text: So they ran out of gluten free bread at 10 am. I was soooo disappointed. The gentleman there was very kind though. I had tea and a gf scone comped. It tasted more like condensed Hawaiian bread. Different than what I expected but still good. Crestfallen... was so looking forward.

fTG1LbedB8p6HzEM8TaNBw.text: It was our first afternoon tea and it was perfect! The place is pretty narrow but cosy. The waitresses were really friendly and kind. We ordered the classic afternoon tea for two with English breakfast tea and Earl Grey. The afternoon tea was made of : several small brioche sandwiches ( salmon, avocado, beetroot and ham); two delicious scones with cream and jam; three types of brownie ( dark chocolate, blondie and lemon/raspberry ); two meringues; two strawberry marshmallows and finally two cupcakes ( one vanilla blackberries one and a chocolate pistachio one) everything was good, delicious and fulfill! We had an amazing time there. We will go back again and warmly recommended it!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Cute cookie mummy
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Halloween afternoon tea

XvJbzByCcu0nZhYZBM-B6w.text: Another reviewer wrote that "there are some kinks" and I couldn't agree more. I had booked 24 hours prior to our visit, and yet, all that got us was the cramped table by the doorway. Aw!The regular afternoon tea includes 2 marshmallows, meringues, cupcakes, brownies, scones (with jam and clotted cream), and sets of sandwiches..Also each one of you is given a teapot, a small teapot, quite small...I thought the sandwiches were delicious, and very buttery (I think we had parma ham, cold cuts, and chicken). My main gripe was the clotted cream. I like it very clotted, and this had the consistency of margarine. The cupcakes were alright, but then I'm not a cupcake die-hard. Should I recommend one, I'd say go for the dark chocolate and raspberry one, the nutella one is forgettable. The raspberry marshmallow is delicious though! We couldn't finish all our tea tray, and the waitress gave us the remainder in a paper bag. No boxes? Eh, the service is a bit chilly, British experience I guess?Oh and the price for afternoon tea is per person, which I didn't get somehow, so that'll set you back 50 quid for two. A dramatic increase from the past year it seems.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. afternoon tea for two
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

E7D0ptT38rGO1W5kmF-4fg.text: Stunningly beautiful lovely cakes, all frou frou and come hither and delightfully flirtatious. They do good coffee, a range of salad and sarnies at lunch but it is the cakes that are there to seduce. Pleasure writ large.

AwRY8AnJZ3OHWIJPxdmHrQ.text: Fantastic coffee and pastries and a cheery atmosphere. Cheap and cheery--what more could you ask for?

0o02L6jUl5zseNqwfxvgjA.text: Stopped for cupcakes last year, having heard rave reviews. I got two large chocolate cupcakes with spider web decorations on for Halloween. They were £2.50 each (gulp!) but they were very good. Sponge was dense but not leaden, with a good texture, moist and a chocolatey flavour. The icing was a thick layer of truffle-like icing, which went well with the sponge. So v. expensive but a high quality product. They also do lunch dishes and have a reputation for good afternoon teas (although I haven't tried that yet).

4Evq4a0eReSYS-0BKz-5rA.text: Beas of Bloomsbury, came here to meet up with friends, and what a pleasant treat. The atmosphere, décor, and drinks were comfortably high quality. But the cakes were the first I have had in this country that were of the standard of places like Magnolia New York. Pleasantly surprised I bought a box full to take home for the family.

4xHhy7HUiDjJeHUPdUkibA.text: Hmmm, I'm wondering if the previous rant by Thomas may have been a fluke, as I have to agree with the raves.  I stopped in for a cream tea with a friend and had an absolutely lovely experience.  The sweets when I was in were all fresh and well-presented.  Admittingly I had no idea what a cream tea was, so my British friend had inducted me here and I have to say, I'm a fan of the whole experience. It's slightly out of walking distance for me otherwise I would be here more often. You'll eat with your eyes then your stomach.  ... well, on second thought, maybe I should make the effort to walk here to burn off some of the cupcakes.

reJm3N3fvKy-1U5d3X1hiQ.text: Love the coffee, veggie sarnie was great as well. Would love to have an aeropress here but wasn't on the go the last couple times I visited. Keep baking those cakes girls!

bmSuWUEJ38lFgb2S_vFAaA.text: I have to agree with the user (Shoreditch) above, that their coffee is pretty good here, and their cupcakes hit the spot when you're up for a bit of a sugar rush. I'd like to spend more time here, sitting inside for a while instead of having to get everything to go. I remember several small round tables with some comfy, fancy looking chairs that seemed perfect for reading the paper whilst downing a cup of joe. It's nicely located next to a Nero's and I would prefer to go to Bea's instead of next door for something more unique. Besides their cupcakes they seemed to have many other baked goods including some cakes, some cookies, as well as a number of American candy bars.

w0kKXdjfF36dUjCqS6pL4Q.text: I tried bea's cupcakes (passion fruit and orange and chocolate and cherry) and I was soo disappointed. The cake bit was very dry and the frosting did not really have much flavour. So sad as I had read all the great reviews and wanted to love this place. Maybe I wil give them another go to see if I was just unlucky but for me Hummingbird is still the winner hands down.

kLb3FlCIOfgmtUvyVCxVzQ.text: Bea's offers great value for money afternoon tea in a small, friendly and 'buzzy' café environment. The cakes taste as good as they look, and not many people leave without taking home at least one cupcake.

1kHo1C25vhi3RJrd_Z_DeA.text: I went to this small cafe together with my friends along with the vision of a friendly atmosphere, delicious cupcakes and above all good service....We got there at 5pm on a Saturday and all seats were taken but we didn't mind waiting as we had chosen to come here over other places. The staff indirectly tried to tell us to leave, that there would be a looong waiting process, but we got a table in 5 mins! At 5.30pm (They close at 6pm) they started clearing up and cleaning the place and seemed very bothered that people still wanted to be served. At 5.50pm we were told that they close in 10 minutes....If staff are unhappy and rude it's obviously a place which lacks 'soul'. I will not go back and I would advise anyone looking for a cosy cupcake place to go somewhere else.

iwqVQfoNr3SUhRh5ICZijA.text: I stumbled upon this by accident yesterday whilst walking along Theobald Road. The little placard with 'afternoon tea' written on it was all the invite I needed and a quick peek into the establishment itself gave off the most amazing views of bountiful looking cakes and other delicious looking sweet treats. The place itself was fairly quiet on a Friday afternoon but still buzzy as there just happened to be a film crew and a photographer in situ (random but nice). There is seating for about 20 or so I would say indoors and outside seating consisting of 2 round garden tables + chairs. I went for the Afternoon tea as I am a cream tea freak and have been known to engineer a trip to Cornwall just for this! I loved the presentation of my tea, the jam came in its own little quaint glass jar with a spoon (more than enough for the 2 scones it comes with) and there was the most amazingly luscious tasting clotted cream on the side served nicely chilled. The scones were so light and quite sweet and not at all stody or rock-cake looking (gosh, does that make any sense!). As mentioned I LOVE cream tea and I am not known to ever leave any but I was so full up on the beauty of it all that I left half a scone in the end - very very filling for something so lightly baked. As a non caffeine drinker, it was nice to have a choice of herbal and fruit tea on offer, though a customer did mention that the coffee was lush. My word not his! A birthday cake made to order was picked up whilst I was there and it looked dreamy and I think a future cake order is imminent. On a girly note, I adored the wallpaper that backed the serving area; tres chic and yes, very Parisian Oui! The whole place is cute and twee and definitely worth visiting so make sure you do. It would also be great for a birthday party/lunch for a treasured daughter/little sister/god-daughter methinks. Or at least I think so! The nearest tube station is Chancery Lane but Farringdon is not that much further.

gMjSR3CD66KApXvOgw5LeA.text: Cupcakes, gourmet lunches, decent coffee. There's a lot to love about this little eatery on Theobald's Road. I especially like how Bea's is just a short walk from my flat ... and that it's just across from Gray's Inn with its huge grassy lawn. The perfect solution for an impromptu picnic (londonist.com/2009/03/be…) . Last tasty treat I picked up at Bea's was a cup of crab chowder. I appreciate their ever changing menu - I just hope Bea will keep that one around and on heavy rotation. Yum. For dessert, you can't beat their cupcakes (londonist.com/2008/02/qu…) .

8ULtnXdrRcUiYYPj0xycwQ.text: This is quite simply one of the best places in London. I amk so lucky to work 5 minutes away ... I went the day it opened, right after a visit to the dentist across the street and sat staring at the white chocolate blondie till the anasthetic had worn off.  The blondies are simply fantastic, especially when they are so squidgy you have to eat them with a spoon -  the cheesecake is amazing, ditto the cookies: peanut butter and snickerdoodle are my favourites. And the salads for lunch are incredible. Last week I got lunch there 3 times and ended up buying another identical small box of salad every time to take home for dinner. Roasted sprouts with dried cherries and pancetta... pasta with roasted butternut squash and goats cheese, chicken in a thyme sauce, roasted sweet potato with cumin seeds, carrots and parsnips... if I had to list all my favourite foods I couldn't do any better.... and I've even got a couple of those blondies in the freezer at home - just in case of a dessert emergency.

CXA-dDHG4Qthw5aaj3H2ig.text: Bea's goes to show how tea shops can come in all shapes prices and colours. its not your average dainty Cath Kidston retro vintage whatchamacallit. Artisan is the more apt word. I visited on a saturday as I'd heard there was limited seating. I got a nice table, with lovely cupcake and then was still hungry so ate the their roasted veg and halloumi ciabatta. I like the chef bit at the back and the decor was very Parisian..

XX_i9dNRIk8z17b07svwDQ.text: One of the many bakeries to jump on the popularity of the cupcake, Bea's is probably the prettiest of the lot and the one capitalising the least on child-like whimsy. In fact, Bea's has the sort of neo-Victorian style that will appeal more to grown-ups. And why not? A good alternative to a pub or a chain coffee house, Bea's is a great place for coffee and conversation. And cake, of course.In addition to trendy cupcakes, they have more averagely sized cakes, mini Victoria sponges and flavoured meringues the size of your fist. If you're not interested in coffee (though it is good coffee - no instant here), they have a selection of posh fizzy drinks. The staff are lovely, too. I saw a booth of theirs at a food fair and asked about an item I didn't remember from the shop. They cheerfully informed me that I called a day or two in advance they would do their best to have it when I came 'round. It's an offer worth taking them up on.

wx4cEC2M6eRWXjzKJleO3w.text: I must admit, I wasn't looking forward to a sweet breakfast, but it was actually very good. It's hard to resist the towers of cakes and muffins that greet you as you walk in which this place is famous for, but instead I opted for the porridge, with lots of lovely brown sugar and dried fruit on top. Normally porridge that isn't your own can taste like lumpy diluted cardboard soup (if there is such a thing!?) but this one was creamy, sweet and very tasty. They brew the lovely monmouth coffee here too, which on a Friday morning always hits the spot. The cheesecake looked incredible and I'll definitely have to come back to try something naughty and sweet, but maybe to take away. I just have one gripe with this place - you can see right into the kitchen which usually is a really good thing, especially in a sushi restaurant or a bustling kitchen, but here the bakery is really clinical and all I could see when sipping my coffee was the first aid box and hand towels on the wall also they started cooking the lunch menu and my eyes are still stinging and running from the onions throughout our breakfast! Sorry Bea's, that lost you a 5th star - yummy food and coffee, but maybe use less onion next time??

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

K8e071iR-FpJzJ1MSU16xw.text: Bea's has to be one of my favourite bakeries in London. I've never had anything that was less than perfect. The quality of the products is outstanding and the staff is friendly and efficient. I love the clever designs for special cakes and the super flavour combos for their cupcakes. Don't forget the savouries too. Bea's quiches are perfect and the best I've ever tasted - even compared to ones in France. My only complaint is that I don't walk by Bea's every day to get my fix!

QVXx7lBsm0RjlbzTEhcsNg.text: The only place in Holborn to get a decent cappuccino---and of course, it's two doors down from Caffe Nero, where the milk is so burnt and overfrothed, it resembles candy floss. Cakes aren't anything to sneeze at either.

0eGQlRMgoGBEwdlnapa_5w.text: Great coffee, super cakes and found the lunchtime savoury options a real treat. Decided to get a cake for my boyfriend's birthday party and the manager looked after me wonderfully helping me pick out the perfect b'day cake!

c2klDHyP2EiKtnV_8rqN9w.text: coffee's are amazing but that's not the only treat you get here. from the outside, you see wedding cakes (a specialty) that look like dresses and cupcakes that just makes you smile. once inside, you can smell the freshly baked breads and savories from the open kitchen. during brunch (saturdays) and lunches, you can have exotic salads, sandwiches (from their own bread), soup (with massive portions and man their good!!), quiches are a must, pasta, curries, chili, etc. The thing is, the menu changes constantly so you're always experiencing something new; I've never been disappointed. It's a must go place and one of my favorites. And to top it off, all the staff are super friendly!

XKyK8oI1s71Sqd6IK_3YPw.text: A tiny, cosy place, where you can try different kinds of tasty cakes and cupcakes. The carrot cake cupcakes and also the rum truffle cupcakes are delicious and the flavours are mixed well. The service is not so fast, but this is not from a big importance to me.

2TNFPmsvfusfijZTVBnpSQ.text: Bea's was, by far, the most ADORABLE high tea experience I've ever had! Though the interior is fairly small and best for small groups, it's nicely decorated and pleasantly organized, making it feel like as much a real, functioning cafe as it is a cutesy "tea room". The afternoon tea service features a pot of tea and a 2-tiered collection of scones and desserts. Judging by the other photos, it looks like you get a different cupcake every time, depending on the day/season. The other sweet things were small brownies, blondies, meringues and fancy marshmallows, plus the obligatory scones (very fresh!) with jam and clotted cream. Aside from the tea service, Bea's also offers salads, sandwiches, and a mouthwatering collection of cakes, cupcakes and other desserts. It took everything in me to resist buying more cupcakes after I'd finished the tea. The best part is that this fabulous afternoon tea experience was only £10 per person (as of Oct. 2010. It's gone up to £12 now but that's still a fantastic deal). This was the reasonably-priced, adorable-sans-pretentiousness afternoon tea that my mother and I hoped for years ago on our last vacation -- now we know exactly where to go!

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Halloween-themed cupcakes
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

aKPEr5MU9VH64RCuIzuhcw.text: Some of the best scones in the country! I wish they delivered them...internationally!

vGVXm6KZwxOgTuTNNbvFJw.text: I agree with Mariah B.'s comment concerning greeting customers. I too was ignored - the shop was moderately busy, but not THAT busy.The cupcakes I had were very dry and just not very good. And ridiculously expensive.I won't be recommending this shop.

3BrqzgdBnIOf1AhseQgLTw.text: Wow, this place is awesome! My friend and I were lucky enough to book a table when BoB installed themselves as a pop-up cafe in the Charles Dickens Museum - divine! The service is ace and the cakes were awesome. My friend and I, being the gluttons that we are, opted for the £10 afternoon tea, which is a selection of sugary yummy things complemented by a big pot of your selection of tea. Unfortunately I wasn't super hungry and couldn't finish everything, but the friendly types who work there offered to bag them up which made for a delicious post-dinner treat. The cafe wasn't lively at the museum but was extremely refined and the quick tour I gave myself was great - what a pleasure to be in the same place as one of the world's literary greats! I'm guessing from the previous reviews the permanent premises is quite the place to be seen, so I think I'll have to go there to find out for myself.

5bizyS3ILNFcZc4O63Fxxw.text: Unassuming little cafe frontage on busy Theobald's Road, opens up into a beautifully chic little cafe. It was worth the 10 minute walk through the park from King's Cross. It doesn't have the nicest of views, though as we sat outside on the first sunny day of the month I couldn't help but be grateful it wasn't on nearby pedestrianised Lamb's Conduit Street. Cupcakes of this quality would ensure a permanently packed front stoop.A light passionfruit and vanilla cupcake came with a fresh drizzle of fresh fruit across the top and was light and creamy with the two flavours matching well. A raspberry and chocolate cake was a real hit. Luscious, smooth and velvety, the dark, almost liquid centred chocolate sponge accompanied the raspberry buttercream perfectly. Our final cake was a chocolate piece studded with blueberries. Sadly the blueberry either wasn't present, or didn't come through in the flavour of the cake, but it was still a treat. Definitely worth fighting through the fashionistas on a sunny afternoon for artisan cakes and wonderfully friendly service. They also do mail order, events and party catering too. A lovely local gem that deserves some support.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom

254XAVsyGNSxIT-JjwtUsg.text: This little cafe/bakery has so much to offer. Aside from Bea's signature cupcakes and pastries, there is awesome coffee and a full gourmet breakfast and lunch menu which changes from day to day. Unlike many coffee shops in London that truck in their food from some distant factory, everything at Beas is made from scratch on premises.Full disclosure: I am an old friend of the owner, Bea Vo.

seMlWhTBmul6jm0uOZHjoQ.text: If you're craving for some amazing cupcakes and brownies, this is the place to go. I strongly recommend the afternoon tea on weekends, which my friends and I indulged in one fine Sunday in August after a hen night out. For £12 per person, we got practically unlimited servings of cupcakes and finger sandwiches, along with a pot of Jing tea. It was wonderful, and just a perfect way to recover from a late night out. We also had Bea's custom design two cupcakes with photos of her and her soon-to-be husband printed out as edible photos and placed on the cupcakes. They turned out very well and were amazingly affordable and, well, the look of pleasant surprise on my friend's face said it all really. If, on the other hand, you're not set on eating your body weight in cakes when you're here, then try the chai latte. I'm usually a coffee drinker, but the chai is seriously good.

xXhPL2FVKTUFMCse8lvNgQ.text: Full review at thehappinessprojectlondo…  Since when did cupcakes and afternoon tea become so trendy? My earliest experience of afternoon tea was at the Edinburgh zoo tea room and Bettys in Harrogate  all scones, doilies and blue rinses; and not a single skinny jean in sight. However, like the denim shirt, what was once considered naff can become high fashion, and in London cupcakes and tea are like soooo hot right now. I recently loved afternoon tea at the Wolseley, and at the Bath Spa; and I'd love to try it at the Ritz, the Dorchester and Fortnum & Mason. But a little less Miss Marple, and easier on the wallet, is Bea's of Bloomsbury, half way between Holborn and Chancery Lane. I have to say I have a savoury rather than a sweet tooth. Like Joey from Friends, the sandwich is probably my favourite food group, and I'd take a cheese board over pudding any day. That's not to say I don't like chocolate  far from it, especially at 4pm during my working week  but I don't tend to crave sweet things. However, walking into Bea's, you can't fail to notice how pretty everything looks. Pink swirly cupcakes, huge plates of giant macaroons and meringues, sweets, biscuits. Sugar heaven but not at all twee  there's no pink china or doilies (shame actually!). We sat down and ordered cute little pots of tea and tiered treats. Starting from the bottom, the trays were filled with delicious scones (served with clotted cream and jam), marshmallows, tiny brownies and shortbread, then up to wildly adorned cupcakes (LOVED the be-glittered ones!) and macaroons. The scones were lovely  perfect with jam and tea  and the cupcakes were amazingly soft and moist and incredibly sickly sweet and covered in gloops of sugary icing but still yum yum yum. As I said, my fantasty-island tier would include little cucumber and cheese sandwiches, but this was bloody good. Not used to sweet things, and seemingly born with an inability to stop eating when full, I managed to leave feeling a little sick from the sugar rush, which left me slumped in my chair with only the promise of impending white wine to wake me up. I think I've read somewhere about poor service and I have to say the staff weren't the friendliest I've ever met, but nothing outrageous, and sadly in London trendy venues can be the victims of their own popularity and forget to treat customers like kings and queens (as they always do at somewhere like the Wolseley). Although the food is a treat so the service should be the same really. It wouldn't put me off going back though  it is the PERFECT place to take your sweet-toothed friends, or your mum, or visitors to London who haven't realised that tea and cupcakes are trendy again, an alternative date venue, and a gluttonous alternative to wine-filled sessions with girlfriends.

Imy2AUg6yuE0VPZnJMHbsg.text: My friend and I were actually very disappointed the day we visited Beas. We reserved a table for Saturday and pre ordered high tea. Everything looked lovely, however after our first bite, we both realised that most of the cakes and treats were quite dried out. There was a possibility that everything had been laid out earlier and perhaps exposed, hence the lack of moisture.I really don't like giving bad reviews! I did contact the manager, who apologised and said she would look into it. We were offered a box of six cupcakes by way of a gesture, but we don't want them! We much prefer Betty Blythes!

8VE3OtPZ6RxE7PLHDNjttA.text: I was very ill after visiting this coffee shop. When I telephoned the manager she could barely speak english and when I emailed Bea she implied it was my own fault. That I had somehow eaten too much.The service was slow and the furniture looks like it is from south east asia the tables are awful, wonky etcAvoid this place.

8zQacuLCpSP-X7lHkG2GYQ.text: We were couriered 18 of their cupcakes by a client as a thanks for projects the company I work for had just completed and I have to say they were absolutely divine! They were everything a cupcake should be, and left all these other so-called cupcakes dead in the water. With everyone jumping on the cupcake bandwagon these days, from muffins with icing, to pure stodge, it's nice to know that at least at 1 place in London you can get quality through and through. Thanks Bea's for the best cupcakes in town!

YsiqEoP-_ZZOUxUM1t3MIg.text: Just not impressed. I got unfeasibly excited about going to Bea's last week and was very disappointed by the experience. I phoned a couple of days in advance to order a batch of gluten free cupcakes as a birthday treat for a friend but when I arrived on the collection day there was no record of my order. As the salesgirl scrabbled around trying to find out what had happened I admit to being somewhat awestruck by the fantastical cakey creations that surrounded me - the place is worth a visit just to look - but the increasing worry that my bike ride across London had been in vain and I would have to turn up empty handed to meet my pal prevented me from full enjoyment. When it turned out the order had definitely disappeared, not been processed or whatever I was told I was in luck, because they happened to have plenty of the gluten free cupcakes in that day anyway. Oh, lucky me! In the end my friend was very pleased with her birthday treat so I was happy on that score, though disappointed not to particularly enjoy MY cakes! They were quite dry, bland and had far too much excessively creamy topping, possibly added to mask the lack of flavour everywhere else. They weren't cheap either - I paid £15 for 6 cupcakes and some bite-size bits of raspberry meringue (these were gorgeous) - and I have to say I'd be happier getting lovely moist 2 for £1 muffins from Sainsburys next time I need a cake fix. Style over substance.

geWYUdOEfDVP1_PY6nqmpw.text: Ooooh this place is going to become a firm favourite. Why haven't I been there before? Well, because it's kinda in London nomansland. That bit inbetween Central and Clerkenwell is a little bit weird isn't it? Unless you actually have a reason to go the area, it's not the kind of place you'd stumble across. But it's worth the trip on its own. I was there for a meeting yesterday and we ended up staying for three hours. THAT is the power of a decent cafe. The staff are friendly and happy to help, the cakes are STUNNING (individual lemon meringue tart anyone?) and it's the perfect place to just sit and while away an hour or so. Their choice to stock Luscombe organic drinks just adds to my happiness - I'm powerless before sparkling clementine juice. I was tempted by the afternoon tea - at £8 for a cupcake, scone and three mini desserts as well as a pot of tea it's a bargain. But, I'm just going to have to pop back and try that. Maybe Bea's cute little shitzu puppies will be there again. I liked them. Even though the latte I had wasn't anything to shout about, there's nothing I dislike about this place. It's not cheap but you get what you pay for - wonderful, stunning cakes that have been made with thought and care. There's even a few seats outside if the weather holds out. I can see it becoming a firm favourite.

5gBnRllCK69OgupS9JXQQA.text: I moved to the area a few weeks ago and I was dying to try Bea's. Today, I did. Oh, dear. What a disappointment. We went at 3pm, wanting to avoid a queue. There was a queue, albeit small. Here are my opinions: 1) The layout is awful. Just a narrow strip of cramped tables. At the rear is the kitchen, on display, but in all honesty, it should be hidden. It's just your average messy commercial kitchen. Nothing to show off about! 2) The staff today (31/3/10) were charmless and slack. There seemed to be lots of them but none of them in the least bit interested in doing their job. We had to ask, repeatedly, for anything we wanted. No attention paid at all. I so wish I hadn't wimped out and left a tip! 3) Finally: the cakes. Hmm. Obviously I can't speak for the whole menu, but the (very large) slice of gateau I had was rubbish, really. Far too much sugar and buttercream and far too little cake. Far too little skill, in fact. My companion had a cupcake which also looked fab but, again, was all mouth and no trousers. No better than the stuff they sell in, say, Gregg's. I'd expected proper patisserie. When I think about the snotty comments some peeps make about Patisserie Paul or Patisserie Valerie I want to laugh. They may be chains, but their produce is very acceptable. I'm really sorry to have written this, because, as I said, I just moved to the area and I'd hoped Bea's would be a "find". It absolutely was not. It was expensive, over-rated and complacent. I shan't be returning. YMMV, as they say.

BOpuHI7QakQ3C4ZwlTHhDg.text: I found out about Bea's via "I Know A Great Little Place" and decided that it would be ideal for my best friend's hen party.  An email to the general info address led to a quick, friendly, helpful response, informing me that whilst they wouldn't be able to accommodate the entire group during their regular opening hours, it would be possible to hire out the place for a mere £20 per head for unlimited cakes and sandwiches, plus £2.50 per head corkage if we wished to bring our own booze.Good deal, I thought.  But not wishing to risk untested waters on an event of such importance, I roped in my little sister for an advance recce.  We pitched up one Saturday afternoon to try it out on the sly, sampling the afternoon tea menu as regular punters, with fantastic results.  The tea selection had flavours I had never seen before, yet was not so extensive that I was left incapable of making a choice.  The sweet treats were loving presented on a cake stand and we found ourselves full almost to bursting less than half-way through.  Still, so delicious were they that we soldiered on regardless, munching our way through cupcakes, marshmallows, scones, meringues, brownies and blondies - all home-made, all delicious, and all wonderfully, refreshingly, not overly-sweet.  Despite arriving practically at the end of the afternoon, the staff were all friendly and attentive and we never felt rushed at all.I immediately went home and confirmed the hen night booking.  There then began a succession of emails: panicked on my side, calm and helpful on Bea's.  They did everything they could to help me plan and even agreed with no complaints whatsoever to refund me when one of our party dropped out the day before.The event itself was so successful that I can barely believe it even now.  I arrived at 6pm and they were gently ushering out the remaining customers, so that I could get on with decorating - not that I needed to do much since the place is already so elegant and welcoming.  By the time the group arrived at 6:30, the counter was already groaning under the weight of both sweet and savoury delights; all of the cakes we had tried during afternoon tea plus some delicious tiny baguettes which genuinely were endless.  As soon as a platter appeared to be running dry, another would miraculously appear in its place.  And throughout proceedings, the staff were cheery, delightful and even joined in, helping with music for the games.  They didn't even bat an eyelid at our Butler In The Buff . . .To top it all off, as we got ready to leave we discovered that they had generously packed up all of the remaining food into individual party bags for us; a welcome treat for the miserable post-club journey home some six hours later.I literally cannot recommend this place highly enough, and will do so to anyone and everyone I meet.  It's astonishingly good value for money, even for a cash-strapped underling like myself, and I can't wait to return.

photos.caption: Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bea's of Bloomsbury - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea for two at Bea's of Bloomsbury

LiMmrREvFM413nVVA_gJOw.text: The cakes are delicious here.  Cupcakes, Guinness chocolate cake, are some of my favourites.  Also love their selections of tea!  Prices are a bit high for what the food is, but it's a nice treat.  Lunches here are great too - note that the small box is not great value for money (but the big one is, but is a bit too much food!)  Wish they offered a mid-size option.

C4bF0b0RDa0oZJLY1QZqWQ.text: A very pretty place to have a light bite, some coffee and something sweet as a treat. The window displays alone are worth the visit but venture inside and you'll pick up the vibe. It can get busy so we grabbed a seat outside as inners was full up. Enjoyed the cappuccino's and the brownie was very, very good. Bought some boxes of home-made pomegranate marsmallows. They were beautifully presented in black boxes tied with violet ribbon and made great little gifts.

KzJC6v7FPeBj1t16tOz3GA.text: Lovely lovely cake shop that does take away tea and picnics in the summer. The cakes are amazing and beautifully decorated. Lunch is a bit pricey for the chicken and salad box at £5.90 but the salads vary daily and are yummy. Highly recommend.

mqhkekuD9wmsZeHhNs7f-A.text: This is the perfect place for afternoon tea! The customer service was not the best, but it was still an enjoyable experience when you have good company. My friend and I arrived and we ordered and sat near the pastry section, already tempted by the sandwiches and the pastries. We both ordered the 6 pound afternoon tea, which came with tea of your choice, and 2 scones. I also gathered the courage to order a red velvet cupcake, which was delicious!. The one complaint i have is that the tea came long before the scones, which took awhile to make, but the scones were delicious!. They made them and baked them fresh, so when we received them they were hot out of the oven. They also came with butter and delicious jelly. It was a great tea time in London, and is better than Harrod's which is overpriced for the same thing, only Bea's is more authentic and delicious!
